bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Jefferson Randolph Kean, February 1, 1941

div1.p: Truby feels that he has provided Hench information in accordance with Kean's views and hopes they have provided Hench with better information than what he gathered in Cuba.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Jefferson Randolph Kean, February 1, 1941
div1.p:
I am inclosing my reply to Dr. Hench's long
letter to me of Jan 7th. He has sent you a
copy of that letter and I thought you would be
much interested in my reply, for many details are
brought out which are important. I think you will
find the information I have given him in general
accord with your views. I hope you still have
the letter of Jan 7th so you can understand my
replies. In writing to Gen Ireland recently I told
him to let you know that this letter of mine was come
so that you could held Hench's until this one came.

Mrs Truby & I were very much pleased with your
Christmas Card. It was not only a fine pictures of
you & Mrs Kean, but it was full of that grand old
“atmosphere” that makes old Georgetown so inspiring
I shall frame it and hang it in my den. I am
quite a carpenter, a much better one than a scribe,
and so if you will send me copy of that card I will
make you a nice frame for it.

With affectionate greetings for you both
from Mrs Truby & me -

closer.seg:
P.S. I wish you & General Ireland could get together
and one of you read Hench's letter and the other
read my reply. In that way Hench might get a
better insight in what went on in Cuba in 1900.
I think he is fair minded, but he certainly needs
some better information those he picked up in Cuba.
Havana is the last place in the world to get info. rethis subject,
Note Gen. Ireland and I read these two letters
aloud on Feb 26, 1941.
